$! You don't pay tax on income below your Personal Allowance. But you must pay tax on all your income above it. $

##Income Tax rates and bands

^You only pay tax at these rates on income above your tax-free Personal Allowance. ^

Rate | 2011 to 2012 tax year | 2012 to 2013 tax year | 2013 to 2014 tax year
- | -
Basic rate 20% | £0-£35,000 | £0-£34,370 | £0-£32,245
Higher rate 40% | £35,001-£150,000 | £34,371-£150,000 | £32,246-£150,000
Additional rate 50% (45% from 6 April 2013) | Over £150,000 | Over £150,000 | Over £150,000 

###Income Tax on savings interest

Savings interest is automatically taxed at 20%. But if you're on a low income, you may be able to get the [interest tax-free or get half of the tax repaid.](/apply-tax-free-interest-on-savings)

##Income Tax allowances

Allowance | 2011 to 2012 tax year | 2012 to 2013 tax year | 2013 to 2014 tax year
- | -
Personal Allowance | £7,475 | £8,105 | £9,205
Age 65 to 74 - Personal Allowance | £9,940 | £10,500 | £10,500
Age 75 and over - Personal Allowance | £10,090 | £10,660 | £10,660

###If you become 65 or 75 during the 2013 to 2014 tax year

You won't get the higher age-related Personal Allowance. 

If you become 65, you will still get the basic Personal Allowance of £9,205 for the 2013 to 2014 tax year.

If you become 75, your Personal Allowance will stay at £10,500 for the 2013 to 2014 tax year.

###If you're over 65 now

For every £2 your income is above £24,000, your Personal Allowance goes down by £1.

You may also be able to claim [Married Couple's Allowance.](/married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance")

###If you're blind

You may be able to claim [Blind Person's Allowance.](/blind-persons-allowance "Blind Person's Allowance")

####Blind Person's Allowance 

2011 to 2012 tax year | 2012 to 2013 tax year | 2013 to 2014 tax year
- | -
£1,980 | £2,100 | To be announced

###If your income is over £100,000

For every £2 your income is above £100,000, your Personal Allowance goes down by £1.
